Award.AbstractNarration:
Laparoscopic surgery is a popular alternative to open surgery due to the considerable reduction of recovery time, pain and complications. However, limited access to the operating field, indirect vision, and operating rooms (OR) originally built for open surgery conspire to make the surgeon's work more difficult and inefficient. The goal of the proposed work is to provide a smart OR system to improve safety and procedural success while reducing cost. To achieve this goal, the team will focus on: a smart trocar prototype that automatically recognizes the laparoscopic instruments and allows the accurate reconstruction of the time line in any minimally invasive surgery; and, a smart trocar that provides an accurate 3D localization of the tip of the laparoscopic instruments.

The proposed technology will provide essential information to improve the management of any minimally invasive procedure, reduce cost, and improve performance. In addition, the proposed technology will dramatically advance the technology of the OR by setting up a new REal Time Interactive Navigation Assistance (RETINA) for Surgery that provides robust directions to improve safety. Real time parallel computing, robust computer vision and finite element simulation are the main three complementary building blocks of this OR system. Accurate assessment of the surgeon & smart OR interaction by surgical training experts and close collaboration with industry will provide guidance to the agile development of the OR service.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We are designing an innovative smart OR system that provides a broad spectrum of services to improve patient care. From the quality of process perspective, our system will provide essential information to improve the management of any minimally invasive procedure, reduce cost, and improve performance. Our technology will also dramatically advance the technology of the OR by setting up a new REal Time Interactive Navigation Assistance (RETINA) for surgery that provides robust directions to improve safety. Real time parallel computing, robust computer vision and finite element simulation are the main three complementary building blocks of this OR system. Accurate assessment of the surgeon & Smart OR interaction by surgical training experts and close collaboration with our industry consortium provide guidance to the agile development of the OR service.

This NSF I-Corps experience had a major impact on the way we are developing our research and translate our work into the real world. We have done major investment in time to start ORintel, that is the spin off of this project, and contact major investors. One STTR was submitted to NSF last June in order advance further the product. The market discovery process is still going on and we are adapting our strategy as we learn.

Preliminary discussion with the FDA seems to confirm the validity of our approach.

Several meetings with the leadership of Karl Storz America based in LA have advanced our agenda.
